instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the classification results for classifying the origins of chicken eggshells based on Mycoplasma synoviae infection and how far can this metric go?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the classification results in the related study is the F-score factor. The F-score is a measure that combines precision and recall, providing a balanced assessment of the classification performance. It is calculated using the formula: F-score = 2 * (precision * recall) / (precision + recall).

The F-score can range from 0 to 1, with a higher value indicating better classification performance. In this study, the obtained results of the F-score factor for the classification of the origins of samples show that the percentages of eggs coming from Mycoplasma synoviae infected hens are up to 87% for white eggshells and 96% for brown eggshells. Therefore, the F-score metric in this study can go up to 1, indicating a high level of accuracy in classifying the origins of chicken eggshells.

instruction: How does the machine learning algorithm classify the origins of chicken eggshells based on Mycoplasma synoviae infection?
Output: The machine learning algorithm classifies the origins of chicken eggshells based on Mycoplasma synoviae infection by using a multispectral portable fibre-optic reflectometer and signal processing patch. The sensor device collects reflected spectral data from short spectral bands in the visible (VIS) and near-infrared (NIR) regions. This data is obtained by introducing single-color LEDs to the sample via a fibre bundle. The reflected signal is then pre-processed and input into the machine learning algorithm. The algorithm used in this case is the support vector machine algorithm, which is trained to classify the origins of the eggshells. Three different types of data normalization are applied to enhance the accuracy of the classification. The results obtained from this classification method show that the algorithm can identify the origins of the samples with high accuracy, with percentages of up to 87% for white eggshells and 96% for brown eggshells coming from Mycoplasma synoviae infected hens.
